page.title: 01THE CAMBRIDGE SUFFOLK BORDER
page.content: This area of rolling countryside spans the valley of the infant Stour. It includes the Suffolk village of Great Bradley and the Cambridgeshire hamlet of Carlton. The district is rural with the accent on arable farming. There is some pasture on which store cattle are fattened. Enlargement of fields has resulted in loss of hedges but the skyline is punctuated by areas of ancient deciduous woodland. At the eastern edge, the outlet of an underground water system debouches into the realigned Stour. Work is provided on local farms and at a large family in Carlton which trains, boards and exports dogs. Other employment involves commuting to the racing centre of Newmarket, the university city of Cambridge and the modern industrial town of Haverhill. All residents require private transport.
